item.title: U.S. launches strikes in Syria targeting Islamic State fighters after American deaths
item.description: The Trump administration launched military strikes in Syria to "eliminate" Islamic State group fighters in retaliation for an attack that killed two U.S. troops and an American interpreter a week ago.

item.title: Where ISIS is still active today
item.description: The Islamic State lost its territorial stronghold in the Middle East years ago, but its influence didn't disappear. NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Aaron Zelin about how ISIS looks now.

item.title: Cuba on edge as U.S. moves against Venezuela risk fuel shortages and deeper isolation
item.description: Cuba is watching nervously as the U.S. ramps up pressure on Venezuela, threatening a lifeline and deepening the island's isolation.

item.title: After years of war, Palestinians in Gaza bring back Christmas celebrations
item.description: Palestinians in Gaza are slowly bringing back Christmas celebrations after more than two years of war. The Holy Family Church in Gaza City gathered this week to decorate the church.

item.title: EU leaders agree on $105bn Ukraine loan, but without relying on frozen Russian assets
item.description: European Union leaders have agreed to provide a massive interest-free loan to Ukraine to meet its military and economic needs for the next two years. The loan will not rely on frozen Russian assets.

item.description: The agreement aims to resolve a yearslong standoff between the popular social media platform and the U.S. government over national security concerns tied to China's parent company, ByteDance.

item.description: Australia looks to review its migration laws and crack down on hate speech following Sunday's mass shooting attack at Sydney's Bondi Beach.

item.title: Austrian nuns await word from the Vatican on whether they can stay in their convent
item.description: The three octogenarian nuns broke out of a nursing home to go back to live in their convent, sparking a dispute with their church superior. Both sides have appealed to the Vatican for a resolution.
